article: When my daughter Kelsey was a child, she loved to join me in the garden. To _ chaos in my own garden beds, I provided her with a space of her own, so Kelsey's Corner was born. There she was _ to dig and plant as she wished. Over time, that small piece of land grew into a favorite place in the _ . As she approached high school, Kelsey took her _ off the garden. I didn't _ to accept this change. It seemed acceptable that something as boring as working in the dirt gave way to the mystery of a(n) _ social life, so I began to take care of the space. Even so, I knew it always would be Kelsey's Corner. Now my daughter is eighteen and is in the _ weeks of her high school career. Our mailbox is filled with college admission materials, _ me that the world has come for this young lady and that she will soon answer its _ . Kelsey is looking forward to her wonderful college life _ her mother and I are anxious about the coming life _ our daughter around. Kelsey's Corner seems extremely deserted in this early spring because of Kelsey's leaving. One morning, when I _ past Kelsey's Corner, I noticed some green seedlings had _ at the foot of some dead stalks . It's _ that life is a cycle. Kelsey's leaving is _ one point on the cycle. Now the life wheel will roll with Kelsey as she _ into her adult life. Let her live as she will and let her _ when she can, and whether she comes alone or in _ , she will be welcome home. I'll take care of Kelsey's Corner faithfully. It will also cycle annually, rolling on towards a _ stage of our lives, one that promises a rich harvest.
